title: How to Make White Mayonnaise

steps.headline: Separate some eggs.
steps.description: It is very important to do this thoroughly. Even a speck of yellow is no good. The egg white determines how much mayo will be made; depending upon size, and season, about 1 cup oil, and 1 teaspoon vinegar, to each egg white.

steps.headline: Put the room temp egg white(s) in, preferably, a tallish, skinny olive jar.
Add infusion material.
steps.description: On top of the egg whites, set whatever your mind offers up to you for flavoring the egg white-olive oil frappe. Don't be afraid to get creative here.

steps.headline: Add some vinegar (with "the mother", of course), or lemon juice, or other exotic, acidic juice.
steps.description: Sage and key lime mayo frappé d with homemade, jelled, iced fruit cocktail is sublime...lime juice cooks fruit and jello , so no leftovers (as if)...acids other than vinegar typically need to be doubled to 2 teaspoons. In calculating an exotic acid here, consider what a teaspoon of vinegar (roughly 5% acid) would taste like plain, then understand that that is the impact, roughly, that your acid needs to have.

steps.headline: Don't forget the oil!
steps.description: If you're eating grocery store mayo, you're currently paying extra-virgin, cold-pressed prices for...that? You'll also see that you are  paying free~range egg prices. Add about 3/4 cup of your preferred oil on top of the infusion, reserving 1/4 cup to "fill" the mayo. Your oil should be room temp also.

steps.headline: Mix with a "hand food processor" (immersion blender) for instant mayonnaise (about 4 seconds).
steps.description: Alternate methods will be given their due in a moment. Ground the working end in the bottom of your mayo ingredients, turn it on, and raise slowly (four seconds to a cup). Dribble in extra mayo to "fill" the egg white; experience (and the state of the "gloss" on the mayo) will be your guide. Use immediately or refrigerate. Shelf life about 48 hours.

text: Separate some eggs. It is very important to do this thoroughly. Even a speck of yellow is no good. The egg white determines how much mayo will be made; depending upon size, and season, about 1 cup oil, and 1 teaspoon vinegar, to each egg white. Put the room temp egg white(s) in, preferably, a tallish, skinny olive jar.  Add infusion material. On top of the egg whites, set whatever your mind offers up to you for flavoring the egg white-olive oil frappe. Don't be afraid to get creative here. Add some vinegar (with "the mother", of course), or lemon juice, or other exotic, acidic juice. Sage and key lime mayo frappé d with homemade, jelled, iced fruit cocktail is sublime...lime juice cooks fruit and jello , so no leftovers (as if)...acids other than vinegar typically need to be doubled to 2 teaspoons. In calculating an exotic acid here, consider what a teaspoon of vinegar (roughly 5% acid) would taste like plain, then understand that that is the impact, roughly, that your acid needs to have. Don't forget the oil! If you're eating grocery store mayo, you're currently paying extra-virgin, cold-pressed prices for...that? You'll also see that you are  paying free~range egg prices. Add about 3/4 cup of your preferred oil on top of the infusion, reserving 1/4 cup to "fill" the mayo. Your oil should be room temp also. Mix with a "hand food processor" (immersion blender) for instant mayonnaise (about 4 seconds). Alternate methods will be given their due in a moment. Ground the working end in the bottom of your mayo ingredients, turn it on, and raise slowly (four seconds to a cup). Dribble in extra mayo to "fill" the egg white; experience (and the state of the "gloss" on the mayo) will be your guide. Use immediately or refrigerate. Shelf life about 48 hours. Finished.
